quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs. advising: the core leadership gap
quotes.text: But great leaders know that when you try to advise and have the answer all the time, you're not actually equipping your team to go solve the hard problems. You're training your team to come to you with all of the hard problems.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Captures the core leadership gap: over-advising creates dependency instead of building team ownership and problem-solving capacity.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs. advising: the core leadership gap
quotes.text: There's a misguided view that the goal is to convince the other person that what they're doing is wrong. Actually, the goal of any conflict is to create mutual understanding.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Reframes conflict as an understanding-building exercise rather than a persuasion battle, changing how leaders approach difficult conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs. advising: the core leadership gap
quotes.text: When people are in their gifts and their strengths, they have more energy. We all have more energy when we're operating from the things we naturally are good at.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Offers a practical burnout lever: align work with strengths to increase energy and sustainability.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching vs. advising: the core leadership gap
quotes.text: No, your manager's job is to help you perform in the job you are hired to do. It's your job to navigate your career.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Challenges the expectation that managers should make work fulfilling, emphasizing personal ownership of career direction.

quotes.topic_title: Why conflicts are emotional, not purely logical
quotes.text: We operate in tech. We're supposed to give all of ourselves, all of our time, all of our energy to this endeavor, and it's purely logical.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Challenges the common tech-culture assumption that work and conflict should be approached purely rationally, setting up a more realistic lens for difficult conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Why conflicts are emotional, not purely logical
quotes.text: That's not at all true. It's completely emotional.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A blunt reframe that helps practitioners treat conflict as an emotional dynamic to manage, not just a logical problem to solve.

quotes.topic_title: Why conflicts are emotional, not purely logical
quotes.text: People, when they want to have a conflict, they come in ready to prove their point.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Names a common failure mode—entering “ready to win”—that leaders can watch for and interrupt before a conversation derails.

quotes.topic_title: Why conflicts are emotional, not purely logical
quotes.text: There's a misguided view that the goal is to convince the other person that what they're doing is wrong. Actually, the goal of any conflict is to create mutual understanding.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Provides a practical mental model for reframing conflict from persuasion to shared understanding, changing how you prepare for and measure success in hard conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout preview: energy comes from strengths
quotes.text: When people are in their gifts and their strengths, they have more energy.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A simple burnout-prevention heuristic: energy increases when work aligns with strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout preview: energy comes from strengths
quotes.text: We all have more energy when we're operating from the things we naturally are good at.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Reinforces a practical self-assessment approach: identify what you’re naturally good at and bias your work toward it.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout preview: energy comes from strengths
quotes.text: It's no one else's job to help you live in your gifts.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A responsibility shift that challenges the expectation that organizations or managers should optimize your fulfillment.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout preview: energy comes from strengths
quotes.text: No, your manager's job is to help you perform in the job you are hired to do. It's your job to navigate your career.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A clear division of roles that can reduce resentment and prompt proactive career design.

quotes.topic_title: Show format: live coaching teased and introduced
quotes.text: The power of this is this makes your life so much better.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concise promise of the practical impact of the approaches being introduced—improving day-to-day life, not just work outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Show format: live coaching teased and introduced
quotes.text: Lenny, let's try it. So, I want you to tell me a challenge, something that you're struggling with.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Introduces a live-coaching methodology: start with a real, current challenge to make the conversation concrete and actionable.

quotes.topic_title: Show format: live coaching teased and introduced
quotes.text: She works with CEOs, and founders, and leaders at tech companies on both ways that they are, emotional and positive intelligence, resilience and courage, and what they do, setting vision and strategy, prioritizing, and building trusted and accountable teams.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A useful leadership model that splits growth into “how you are” (inner skills) and “what you do” (execution and team-building).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stripe processed just over $1.4 trillion last year. That figure works out to be about 1.3% of global GDP.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete scale benchmark that helps practitioners contextualize Stripe’s reach and operational complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stripe handles the massive scale and complexity of many of the world's fastest-growing enterprises, including 78% of the Forbes AI 50 and more than half of the Fortune 100.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific adoption stats that signal credibility and can inform vendor evaluation or competitive positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They've also got a category-leading billing solution and a highly-optimized checkout experience built specifically to increase your checkout conversion.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical growth lever—checkout optimization—as a product capability to prioritize for revenue impact.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta helps companies of all sizes get compliant fast and stay that way with industry-leading AI, automation, and continuous monitoring.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for compliance: automate + continuously monitor to reduce ongoing operational burden.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Establishing trust isn't optional. Vanta makes it automatic.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of security/compliance as a default requirement and a candidate for automation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Leaders want to care about the people they work with. They want to empower those around them. But sometimes the busyness of our world gets in the way and the urgency of the litany of things to do distracts you from the people in front of you. And actually, if you really understand the talent around you and you create an environment where they can be successful, your business will thrive.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A practical reminder that prioritizing people and creating the right environment is a direct lever for business performance, not a “soft” nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: it's vulnerable to seek help
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Highlights a key blocker to leadership growth—embracing vulnerability as part of improving management and team-building skills.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: recognizing that if they lean into their gifts and they get back into their purpose, they can have more fun while having an impact on the world.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A purpose-driven mental model: aligning work to strengths and purpose increases both enjoyment and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: People have climbed the ladder in whatever realm they're in because they've been dependable, reliable, the smartest person in the room. But when you're leading a quickly-scaling company, you quickly have less context than the people you're around. And the way you were operating before doesn't work because you don't have the ability to wrap your arms around every problem in a deep way.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A counterintuitive shift for scaling leaders: success stops being about having the answers because your team will often have more context than you do.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've seen leaders at every phase from frontline managers up to running an 8,000-person company struggle with knowing when do I have to have the answer, and when I don't have the answer, what options do I have?
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A reusable leadership diagnostic: deciding when to provide answers vs. choosing other approaches (e.g., coaching) is a universal scaling challenge.

quotes.topic_title: When to advise vs. when to coach
quotes.text: But when you're leading a quickly-scaling company, you quickly have less context than the people you're around. And the way you were operating before doesn't work because you don't have the ability to wrap your arms around every problem in a deep way.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A scaling heuristic: as orgs grow, leaders lose context and must change how they lead instead of trying to stay the primary problem-solver.

quotes.topic_title: When to advise vs. when to coach
quotes.text: But great leaders know that when you try to advise and have the answer all the time, you're not actually equipping your team to go solve the hard problems. You're training your team to come to you with all of the hard problems.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A warning about the hidden cost of always advising: it creates dependency and funnels complexity upward.

quotes.topic_title: When to advise vs. when to coach
quotes.text: You can shift your energy into curiosity when someone brings you a hard problem to solve, and create space to get curious, and help them solve their own problem.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A practical coaching move: replace solutioning with curiosity to enable the other person to own the solution.

quotes.topic_title: When to advise vs. when to coach
quotes.text: If there's an urgent issue, the person coming to you doesn't have the skill they need, that's a time to advise and help.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A simple decision rule for when to advise rather than coach: urgency plus a capability gap.

quotes.topic_title: When to advise vs. when to coach
quotes.text: You have something you absolutely want them to do. You know the right answer. You want them to be motivated to go do it. Advise them. Help them see the path.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A clear boundary condition: if you already know the desired outcome, coaching becomes a guessing game—so give direct advice instead.

quotes.topic_title: Active listening: three levels and a demo
quotes.text: There's actually three levels to listening. So, the first level listening, level one is internal.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Introduces a simple, memorable framework practitioners can use to diagnose and improve how they listen.

quotes.topic_title: Active listening: three levels and a demo
quotes.text: Level three listening is global listening. So, that's what I'm hearing beneath the words. I'm hearing what you're communicating, not just what you're saying.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Defines the highest-leverage listening mode—tuning into emotion, context, and nonverbal cues, not just content.

quotes.topic_title: Active listening: three levels and a demo
quotes.text: So, what I want to invite listeners to understand is that active listening doesn't mean you're setting up an hour coaching session with every person on your team. No one has time for that.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Counters a common misconception and makes active listening feel feasible in real team settings.

quotes.topic_title: Active listening: three levels and a demo
quotes.text: But even in the time you're already spending, just focusing on the other person in a way that is novel and really gives them your full attention so you can see their feelings under what they're saying goes a long way to motivating your team and helping them understand what's actually happening under the surface in this situation.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to apply active listening immediately to improve motivation and surface hidden issues.

quotes.topic_title: Active listening: three levels and a demo
quotes.text: Yeah, there's an element of synthesizing what I'm hearing verbally. That's the focused listening part, and then, mirroring back the emotions that I'm noticing.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Gives a practical method: summarize content plus reflect emotions to create connection and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Powerful questions: the GROW coaching model
quotes.text: So, the GROW model just is four different categories of kinds of powerful questions. So, the G in grow is goal. So, what does success look like? What's the outcome that you want to have? Any question that's around defining the best case scenario. The R in the GROW model is about your current reality. Where are you stuck? What are your current challenges? What have you tried? The O is about your options. So, let's expand the opportunities that you can understand of the choices you have in front of you. What are the various paths you could take? And the W in the GROW model is the way forward. What are you going to do next?
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A practical coaching framework leaders can use to structure conversations from defining success through committing to next steps.

quotes.topic_title: Powerful questions: the GROW coaching model
quotes.text: And you don't have to do it in this order. These are just four kinds of questions.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A reminder to use GROW flexibly rather than mechanically, adapting to what the person already knows or needs.

quotes.topic_title: Powerful questions: the GROW coaching model
quotes.text: Yeah, this is definitely you want to coach when you think the person you're talking to has the right context and can solve their own problem. That's a premise of coaching.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A clear decision rule for when coaching is appropriate versus when direct guidance is needed.

quotes.topic_title: Powerful questions: the GROW coaching model
quotes.text: I think you get curious. "Hey, help me understand how you came to that conclusion because here's my reaction to that." So, you're honest, but you're also curious.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A concrete script for responding to a coachee’s “bad idea” without shutting them down, while still surfacing your concerns.

quotes.topic_title: Powerful questions: the GROW coaching model
quotes.text: So, coaching in a manager or a leader context is not the same as in an executive coaching conversation. You're managing this person. You're responsible for their outcomes. You're not setting up an hour-long coaching session, you're just using coaching as an additional tool in your toolkit from advising. And you're creating more space, maybe 15% more space in your one-on-ones, in your meetings for open-ended questions.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A nuanced model for blending coaching with management accountability, including a specific “15% more space” tactic.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO stops being the decision bottleneck
quotes.text: And soon, he realized that he was the blocker on every decision, every business decision, every product decision.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Highlights a common scaling failure mode where a founder unintentionally becomes the organizational bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO stops being the decision bottleneck
quotes.text: But with some coaching, he realized he was training his team to come to him with every decision because he had always operated that way.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe: the leader’s habits create the dependency they resent, implying the fix starts with behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO stops being the decision bottleneck
quotes.text: So, we really invested in this idea of I'm going to start to set the system up so we have a product review every two weeks, they each have clear KPIs they're driving to that we co-design, and for this next quarter, I'm shifting from the role of deciding on everything to coaching.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Provides an actionable operating system (cadence + co-designed KPIs + explicit role shift) to remove decision bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO stops being the decision bottleneck
quotes.text: I'm going to really ask good questions in our check-ins. I'm going to align to the KPIs, ask how things are going, ask where they're stuck.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Gives a practical coaching script for leaders to replace “answers” with questions while still maintaining accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO stops being the decision bottleneck
quotes.text: The squads are moving so much faster. The teams feel more empowered and motivated.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Captures the concrete outcome of the squad + coaching approach: speed and morale both improve.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s endless work problem
quotes.text: I joke that be careful working for yourself if your boss is a workaholic.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable warning that self-employment can amplify overwork if you don’t set boundaries with yourself.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s endless work problem
quotes.text: I want to ask you, what would dream state look like? So let's say in six months you're still running this beautiful business that you've created. And you feel differently. What is happening?
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A practical coaching prompt for defining a desired future state in concrete, observable terms.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s endless work problem
quotes.text: What's interesting to me is when you're talking about exploring and tinkering, when you first said it, you said it in kind of a spacious way. It's fun to explore and tinker. You're deeply naturally curious. You find new insights. But then I also heard you say, "And it's a way to stay ahead, I have to do it in order to feel like I'm informed." So what do you make of that difference?
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Highlights a useful reframe: noticing when intrinsic motivation quietly turns into pressure-driven obligation.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s endless work problem
quotes.text: And the challenge I run into is I sometimes get that extra time and then I fill it with more projects and opportunities. That's the problem right there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Pinpoints a common failure mode in time management: reclaimed time gets immediately re-committed unless protected.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s endless work problem
quotes.text: So that's a perfect shift into, what are your current ways of operating that get in the way of having that 25% of free time?
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A diagnostic question practitioners can use to identify the specific behaviors that block their stated goal.

quotes.topic_title: Why coaching works: buy-in and asking preference
quotes.text: I do want to name that typically when you're coached versus told what to do, you're more bought in.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Highlights the core mechanism of coaching—buy-in—explaining why it often leads to better follow-through than directive advice.

quotes.topic_title: Why coaching works: buy-in and asking preference
quotes.text: But you're the expert on your own context and actually what resonates. And you're much more likely to do it if you came up with it.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A practical mental model for leaders: treat the other person as the context expert and optimize for self-generated plans to increase execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why coaching works: buy-in and asking preference
quotes.text: No one wants to ... unless you ask for advice, very few people are like, "Please tell me what to do."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that most people resist being told what to do, so defaulting to advice can backfire unless requested.

quotes.topic_title: Why coaching works: buy-in and asking preference
quotes.text: And great leaders often say, "Do you want advice or do you want some space to think about it? Can I help you think it through? Or would you like me to tell you what I would do?"
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, reusable script for leaders to clarify whether to coach or advise, preventing misalignment and increasing receptivity.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout: designing work around strengths and gifts
quotes.text: And it was so sad to see how exhausted that group of incredibly creative and committed leaders was in that moment.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A concrete example from Stripe showing that even top-performing, highly motivated leaders can be deeply exhausted—burnout isn’t just a “low performer” problem.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout: designing work around strengths and gifts
quotes.text: And so what I make of that is that when people are in their gifts and their strengths firmly, most of the time, they have more energy.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A simple causal model for sustained energy: alignment with strengths/gifts is a primary driver of endurance and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout: designing work around strengths and gifts
quotes.text: So I try to help my leaders see that they can design their lives so they're spending 80% of their time in their gifts.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: An actionable target/heuristic (80%) for role and life design that leaders can use to evaluate and redesign how they spend time.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout: designing work around strengths and gifts
quotes.text: So one tool I like to give is for people to actually take two weeks and every night reflect on, what are the five things today that gave me the most energy? And what are the five things that depleted my energy the most?
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic method to identify energizers vs. drainers and uncover patterns that point to strengths and misaligned work.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout: designing work around strengths and gifts
quotes.text: And they're just slowly ... it's like a slow leak in your gas tank that over time shows up in your daily amount of energy.
quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor that reframes burnout as gradual energy loss from chronic misalignment rather than a sudden collapse.
